name: methylene diphenyl diisocyanate production | hydrochloric acid, without water, in 30% solution state | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/26223/documentation

This dataset represents the average production of 1 kg of methylene diphenyl diisocyanate (MDI). At the same time, the formed hydrochloric acid is treated as a valuable by-product. Even though MDI exists in three isomers, 4.4-MDI is the most widely used in industrial applications and is the one represented in this dataset.;MDI (CAS: 101-68-8) is an aromatic diisocyanate that is used in the production of polyurethane foams in combination with polyols (Boustead 2005). Polyurethane foams show good thermal insulation properties, and thus, are used extensively in the manufacture of freezers and refrigerators, and in building and automotive applications. In 2012 the largest producer of MDI globally was Bayer, producing 1.24 million tonnes per year, followed by Wanhua Group, producing 1.1 million tonnes per year (Gal, 2012).;The industrial preparation of isocyanates is carried out with the reaction of an amine with phosgene in an aromatic solvent. In more detail, the production scheme for MDI can be breakdown into the following chemical reactions:;Methylene dianiline (MDA) production from aniline and formaldehyde: 2C6H7N + CH2O -> C13H14N2+H2O;MDA phosgenation: C13H14N2  + 2COCl2  -> C15H10N2O2  + 4HCl;This dataset is based on industry data from five different MDI producers with six plants in five European countries participated in the primary data collection.;References:;Christian Six, Frank Richter (2011): Isocyanates, organic, Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry, Wiley-VCH.;Heino Falcke, Simon Holbrook, Iain Clenahan,Alfredo Lopez Carretero, Teoman Sanalan,;Thomas Brinkmann, Joze Roth, Benoit Zerger; Serge Roudier, Luis Delgado Sancho (2017): Best Available Techniques (BAT) Reference Document for the Production of large Volume Organic Chemicals;2021, ISOPA , Eco-profile of toluene diisocyanate (TDI) and methylene diphenyl diisocyanate (MDI) , 3 - SeparatePublication;G. Margaret Wells, “Handbook of Petrochemicals and Processes”, 2nd edition, Ashgate, 1999;Boustead. 2005. Eco-profiles of the European Plastics Industry Diphenylmethane diisocyanate (MDI). Retrieved from: http://www.polyurethanes.org/uploads/documents/eco_midi.pdf, accessed 26 January 2017;Gal, J. 2012. Wanhua to the rescue of BorsodChem. ICIS Chemical Business. Retrieved from: http://www.icis.com/resources/news/2012/02/20/9533156/wanhua-to-the-rescue-of-borsodchem/, accessed 26 Janury 2017;[This dataset is meant to replace the following datasets:]

The activity starts when the raw materials enter the process.

This activity ends once  the products, i.e., 1 kg of methylene diphenyl diisocyanate and 0.52 kg of hydrochloric acid, are at the production site gate. Materials entering the process are included as well as energy uses, infrastructure and emissions.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2013:Manufacture of plastics and synthetic rubber in primary forms

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data collection for production was collected as 12-month averages representing the year 2018. The inventory creation and calculation stage was concluded in 2020, while the technology is not expected to change until 2026.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Representative 100% of European (EU-28) production of methylene diphenyl diisocyanate.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: This inventory represents the average production of methylene diphenyl diisocyanate (MDI), provided as a generic dataset, starting with aniline and formaldehyde as raw materials.;In more detail, the chemical processes involved in the MDI production are described below.;First, methylene dianiline (MDA) is produced through the reaction of formaldehyde with aniline, in the presence of  hydrochloric acid catalyst. As MDI exists in three isomers, a distribution of MDI isomers is obtained, where their share depends on the ratio of aniline to formaldehyde, the acid concentration, and the reaction conditions.;Methylene dianiline (MDA) synthesis: 2C6H7N + CH2O -> C13H14N2+H2O;The mixture at the reactor outlet is neutralised with caustic soda, and separated into an organic phase and an inorganic (aqueous) phase. The latter phase contains the crude MDA isomer mixture, and is washed. Excess amounts of aniline are recovered with distillation and recycled to the MDA synthesis stage. At the same time, the inorganic (aqueous) phase is further purified from any residual organic substance, and subsequently discharged for additional treatment and recovery stages.;The crude MDA isomer mixture is subsequently treated with phosgene to produce an MDI isomer mixture in solution, along with HCl byproduct.;MDA phosgenation: C13H14N2  + 2COCl2  -> C15H10N2O2  + 4HCl;In absence of phosgene in the form of a raw material, this intermediate is produced on-side from carbon monoxide and chlorine.;Phosgene production: CO + Cl2 -->  COCl2;The crude MDI solution is first separated by the solvent, which is recovered via distillation, and subsequently purified through fractional distillation, crystallisation, or sublimation.;Reference(s):;2021, ISOPA , Eco-profile of toluene diisocyanate (TDI) and methylene diphenyl diisocyanate (MDI) , 3 - SeparatePublication
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: An exchange representing unreacted raw materials that are recycled to the process after treatment, with a representation of 5.6% on dry mass output, was cut-off.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
Industry data, representative 100 % of European (EU-28) production capacity, based on production volumes in 2018.

The industrial data used originate from five different MDI producers with six plants, in five European countries.

exchanges.description: Valuable byproduct of the production technology.

exchanges.description:
Calculated based on literature data published by the industry. For this activity, no information was readily available concerning infrastructure and land-use. Therefore, the infrastructure is estimated based on data from two chemical factories, the BASF site of Ludwigshafen and the chemical factory in Gendorf (which are both located in Germany), which produce a wide range of chemical substances. Based on this data, the following assumptions are made: the built area amounts to about 4.2 ha, the plant has an average output of 50'000 t/a and a lifespan of fifty years. The estimated infrastructure amount is therefore 4.00 E-10 units per kg of produced chemical.

References:
Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.
Gendorf (2000) Umwelterklärung 2000, Werk Gendorf. Werk Gendorf, Burgkirchen.;activityLink introduced to establish a direct link to the corresponding regional supply of this product
